Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2009 11:38AM LRM216 wrote: Chico - I too had trouble on the Adriamycin.  Are you taking Emend both pills and are they putting into the chemo, bowels are a problem on any type of chemo, either constipation, or diarhea.  Stay on top of it with colace for softening at least 4 times a day and Miralex or a another good laxative, if the opposite, then immodium.  YOur onc should be telling you all this.  Do you get the Neulasta shot (I got one after every AC and then after each of my taxotere's).  They are horrible for some of us, but unfortunately, very necessary.  I had tremendous bone pain and muscle spasms starting about 36 hrs. after each Neulasta.  Onc finally gave me oxycodone to take when needed.  It was a life saver.  Key is to take all these meds before the bone pain sets in.  I broke each oxy in half and took half dosage and upped to full if needed.  Should also have compazine and Zofran on hand for stomach achiness or nausea.  You don't sound as if you are armed with all that you need.  Please make sure you have this arsenal on hand - talk to the onc, once my onc knew how bad I was feeling, she went to work on it immediately with the stronger stuff.  You WILL get through this, I promise.  I just finished my rads last week (33 of them) and I am one of those that can honestly say - it has been by far THE WORST 10 1/2 months of my life.  I am triple neg, so at no point could I say "shove this crap - I'm outta here."  You are far stronger than you will ever know.  Hang in there, and get what you need to get through this as best as you can.  This is your life, honey.  Hit it with the big guns and get the onc to accomodate you.  Wishing you a much better time of this. Hugs, Linda

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 12:55PM LRM216 wrote: It is sitting in one spot, not yet invading, so therefore, it is "in situ."  However, IDC (invasive ductal carcinome) develops from DCIS - it is when DCIS leaves it's little comfortable "in situ" house and starts its invasive journey through the duct into the breast tissue that you then have IDC, which is the most common form of breast cancer diagnosed.  Although that was all that was seen and biopsied on me, when I had my lumpectomy, there was DCIS in two of my margins and I need re-excision, so they normally go hand in hand.  Yours has just not gone through the ducts into the breast tissue and no one can tell when it might.  Hope that clears it up for you a little.  Others with a better description will come along to help you understand.  Hang in there and keep us posted.  Wishing you all good things and a gentle treatment. Linda

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 06:55AM LRM216 wrote: Triple negative cancer has no known established therapies other than lumpectomy/mastectomy, agreesive chemo and rads - that's it!  Those of us diagnosed as triple neg, at the advice of our oncs' opinion, usually choose to go as agressive as we can, as that is all we have.  I would strongly urge your mom to go for the most agressive treatment she can.  Of course, as with anything else in life, there are no guarantees, however, I don't ever want to be at some point in this disease where I had to say "if only I did.......".  By the way I am a young 62, a widow raising my 14 yr. old granddaughter and work full time as a legal asst in a large law firm for a heavy working partner and did it all just fine while on treatment (and had loads of side effects!).  I wish your mom the best of luck and a smooth treatment plan.  God bless. Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 07:48PM LRM216 wrote: Hi - I had 4 DD A/C every two weeks x 4 and then was supposed to have 4 DD Taxol every two weeks x 4 - but after my very first Taxol, I developed neuropathy in all my fingers and my feet right out of the gate.  My onc then switched me to taxotere every 3 weeks x 3, as the taxotere is NOT as bad with the neuropathy as either Taxol or even the Abraxane.  She was correct, my neuropathy never worsened, but I did complete my final taxotere Sept 10, 2009 and still have very minor neuropathy in fingertips only, but all my toes are still numb.  They have not caused me any distress other than they feel weird.  She said it could take a year or more to completely go away, which I am hoping to be the case and that I don't have this forever!  The only big problem I had is that with the Taxol you do not need the dreaded Neulasta shot ( which was worse for me than any of the side effects of either the AC or the Taxotere), and I needed it each and every time after all 7 of my chemos (not after the only Taxol I had).  I suffer greatly with the Neulasta, but unfortunately I either got neutropenia each time, or the counts just dropped really low, so I needed it.  Otherwise, I worked full time (am a legal asst.) and used my hands everyday with no problems other than the tingling and numbness.  Out of the two  - I had a much easier time with the A/C - the taxotere was pretty rough with bone pain and muscle aches - and then the Neulasta on top of that, ugh!  But - I made it - and pray to God I never have to go that route again!  Good luck on your chemo journey - it does come to an end, I promise! Kisses to Kilian - Linda

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 06:18PM LRM216 wrote: Lexislove - you said it best.  "I am living under the covers."  I think each and every one of us, no matter what type or stage - can truly feel those words and know just what you mean.  I think we are all living under the covers a great deal of the time.  I can feel strong and confident, and then wham - I read on this board or another - of a fellow triple neg getting it back at 10 or 12 years!  What the hell - so what's happened to that " oh,make it to 5 yrs and your chance of getting it back is less than anyone's!"  There is just no rhyme or reason to this disease, that's what is so frightening.  I used to envy all the HR+ gals for having a cancer that has many avenues to treat - until I began to see so many relapse, etc. after their 5 years of continued drugs were up.  Look at all the Stage IV gals that have just recently passed on -it's sickening.  Most of them were just posting only a week or two before they died.  This disease is a freaking beast - and none of us, once diagnosed, ever stop looking over our shoulder again.  God bless us all.  A cure?????  Yeah, sure, but it's nice to dream. Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2010 11:57AM LRM216 wrote: I had 4 DD Adriamycin and Cytoxin (Red Devil) and one DD of Taxol (got neuropathy right out of the gate in all fingers and toes, so she switched me to 3 remaining doses of DD Taxotere.  I had no heart issues prior to the chemo (and not after either), but my onc does not do the Red Devil without a MUGA scan or an echocardiogram prior to the chemo.  If your onc has not scheduled you for either of the tests I mentioned, I would demand to know why.  I do not know anyone that got it without having the testing done prior.  While I hated every minute of the chemo, I, unlike most of the gals that have had the above combo, had a much more difficult time with the Taxol and taxotere than I did with the AC.  I wish you well and an uneventful journey.  It's not pleasant, but if I did it, you can too.  Just keep telling yourself - "this too shall pass."  I worked full time through it all other than the Thursdays I had my infusions - side effects began to hit on Saturday and Sunday for sure) - didn't bounce into work on Monday - more like a slow crawl.  God bless. Linda

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2010 12:48PM LRM216 wrote: Zoh: I do not post on the Stage IV boards, but I read them diligently and just wanted to let you know that I too had taxotere as my second round of chemo (1 round taxol- taken off taxol and put on remaining 3 DD of taxotere) and I just about wanted to die from the pain.  Like you, it seemed to go on forever.  Just as I was beginning to feel a bit better, my next round was due.  It was horrible.  I felt as though every bone in my body was breaking, and the muscle aches were just horrid.  All I could do to quell some of the pain was to religiously take my oxy every 6rs.  Try not to let the pain cycle be broken.  Take the drugs even if you feel a bit better - at least until you feel a LOT better.  I broke them in half and took half doses as I had to work and function, but it helped a lot.  So very sorry you have to go through this on top of everything else - it is truly a nasty drug for those of us who get the SE's.  On the other hand, it's also supposed to kill cancer's butt.  Best of luck and all good wishes. Linda

Posts.Content: LRM216 wrote: Had my first AC on 4/30 - wasn't totally pleasant, but certainly bearable.  Got through all the ucky parts ok and just was feeling tired, very tired, but went to work, etc.  One week later, went to onc for labs and found out my blood levels dropped so low that I was neutropenic - also my cancer breast (which is still healing from a 4/8 re-excision, but got clearance on from all docs) turned watermelon red with cellulitis (which they say came from the fact that I was neutropenic).  Put in isolation in hospital from Thursday until today (Monday) with constant swabs of breast, which was oozing a bit from the huge scar I have and was on constant iv antibiotics.  In fact, for the next 10 days I must go to the infusion center at 8:00 a.m. (weekend included) for my 1/2 of iv infusion as there are no pills to take as strong as what they are giving me via iv in hopes of clearing up the cellulitis in the breast - permanently, since my counts may go down after each AC (3 more to go - joy).  My counts are now back up but they are not satisfied with the breast so my AC has been extended to every 3 weeks instead of the scheduled 2 weeks.  She said that used to be the normal protocol anyway and I should not worry about it as it will be easier on my levels over 3 vs. 2 weeks.  So, long story short - while I thought I was going to sail through the AC - I got a big surprise.  Can't wait till after #2 on the 21st.  Should be a doozy.  Has this or anything similar happened to any one else, or am I just the lucky winner of this prize? Oh, forgot to add that this coming Thursday, I also get the pleasure of returning to the BS so that they may extract the small pool of fluid detected by US right above a portion of my scar via needle aspiration. Linda Life isn't about waiting for the storm to end, it's about learning to dance in the rain ... Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 09:01AM LRM216 wrote: Susan, I think you are correct in that it seems the oncologist is the one that makes the decision.  One girl on the triple neg board has very low estrogen (I think 3%) and has completed all our "standard" chemo for Grade 3 triple negs, and her doc wants her to now go on the hormonal, but she doesn't want to (she's afraid of the side effects - I'd drink freaking arsenic if they said it might help!), all the others did in fact go on hormonals after their initial "triple neg" chemo and rads were done.  Guess only time will tell, but you might want to search for "triple negative with very low estrogen" and they should pull up - on this or any other sites I mentioned.  I just figured I'd mention it to Carcharm, since this freaking disease is confusing enough, and by reading some of the posts I mentioned, it may have given her a bit more info.  I wish you, and all of us on this board, the best - always, Linda

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2014 08:06AM LRM216 wrote: Cypher: I think it just depends on your onc.  Five years ago when I was diagnosed Stage 1, no nodes BC, my onc insisted that I have full body bone scan,  and full body CT (originally ordered a PET but my insurance refused it so had the CT instead). My BS had already done the breast MRI after my biopsy and prior to my surgery. I know for a fact that she still adheres to that policy today, 5 years later, for the same reason you state in your post.  She feels that even early cancer can have something else hidden and lurking so does these extra tests prior to chemo as a further "look see," and yet I know others I have met along the way with the same stats that had no further testing prior to chemo.  I know it guarantees a big fat nothing in the grand scheme of things, but the extra peace of mind (is there such a thing with BC?) helped an already horrible situation.  It sure would be helpful to all of us if all the oncs were on the same page in regard to further testing prior to treatment.  Sigh.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 07:54PM LRM216 wrote: Hi, I'm Linda and was diagnosed late Feb or 2009.  I just have to add something to the thread and that is, while I was happy to hear I had no node involvement (but AM triple neg - ugh), I must say that being node neg does not guarantee anything at all.  Cancer can still spread through the blood stream and not only through the nodes.  There are many Stage IV gals on this board, as well as the other boards, that also began as "node negative."  While this may seem I am throwing a wet blanket on all of us with neg nodes, I assure you I am not.  Just trying to say that this whole disease, no matter ER/PR+ or negative, nodes or no nodes, it's all such a crap shoot and all each of us can do is believe with all our hearts in our treatments and that they will work for each of us.  I wish for everyone one of us on this thread a smooth treatment plan, uneventful recovery from same, and long lives - cancer free! Linda

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 07:41PM LRM216 wrote: Oh, as an aside, in my original post above, I make mention about the BS stating at my lumpectomy that she was going to request the receptors be done again on the path report, since the biopsy report shows them as triple neg.  Path report doesn't show it at all.  Called her office and spoke with her assistant today and related this - she called me back and said that yes, the doctor was going to order it, but the radiologist didn't feel it was necessary. What is this crap - what does the damn radiologist who I don't even know have to do with this decision.  They made me feel like an idiot.  The john Hopkins site claims that a Needle core biopsy path report showing the receptors could and probably is accurate; however, if the samples were small, then the test might have hit a "negative" spot and that the triple neg could be wrong.  What is so hard about just running a new receptor test on the real stuff from the lumpectomy.  Am I wrong?  Someone please enlighten me.  If I am in error, then I can at least console myself with the fact that I should feel confident in the report on the biopsy and be able to put this to rest.  The last thing I want to be is a pest to my BS; however, this is my life - not hers.  I certainly wouldn't want to be treated from this point on as a triple neg if there was a possibility I wasn't.  Anyone have this happen to them or am I just paranoid as I am so unhappy since the triple neg diagnose. Linda

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 09:57AM LRM216 wrote: Lisa, thanks for your informative post and I agree with you completely.  I have taken a very strong stance as my own advocate as I am not new to the medical field and the mistakes that can and unfortunately often do, along the way.  I have had all the necessary testing required and haven't had to ask for anything additional and have done and will continue to do extensive research on my own.  I have in fact researched via the internet the outcomes of receptor testing via Core needle and the final excisional biopsy and all research felt the concordance between the two was extremely high.  Hence, my call to the oncologist's office.  You must understand, I have not yet seen the oncologist as my first appointment is not until April 15, that is the reason I have spoken to her assistant.  This is a large and very reputable oncology firm here in the Atlanta area.  Perhaps things work differently in other parts of the world or even here in the US, but one does not get to speak to the pathologist on a personal basis.  I attempted to call the pathology department in the hospital (another highly respected cancer center located within a popular hospital here) and could not even be put through.  They just do not speak to you personally. My BS surgeon and the breast radiologist did not feel there was another need for the retesting as I stained 0 on all.  I will of course discuss this once again with the onc in person at my first appt regarding this, but until I get in to actually see her, her assistant is the route one must go through, and I might add she has been wonderful.  Thanks again for your concern and information.  I must add that I was disappointed when doing the research regarding the outcomes of initial biopsy vs. final biopsy - I was so hoping to change this dreaded triple neg to that of er/pr positive.  Don't think I will ever reconcile myself to the fact that not only did I get the dreaded cancer diagnose - but then the second kicker of triple neg.  But, I am not alone, thank God, many other wonderful ladies with triple neg that are surviving it.  Best to you, Linda

Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 11:18AM LRM216 wrote: Unfortunately, I have first hand experience with this.  I had my first A/C (AC + T) on April 30th.  I was totally healthy prior to my diagnose on 2/23 of cancer.  All blood tests were perfect right before chemo - am never sick.  Had Lumpectomy on 3/25 - then re-excision on 4/8.  I have a large incision as I had a "bat wing" procedure done on breast so it is still healing.  On day 7 after my chemo, went for labs at onc's and had a wbc of 0.7 and rbc of 69,000.  I was told I could not go to work for 2 days and had to stay away from children, other people, etc.  That evening I began running a fever and my cancer breast got bright red, hot and hurt even more than usual.  Saw onc the following a.m. as I did not want to go to ER and see a bunch of unfamiliar docs the prior night.  Fever broke during the early a.m. hrs. but onc admitted me to hospital upon seeing me and my breast.  I was in isolation as well.  Remained in hospital for 4 days on Vancomycin and serapeen iv around the clock.  On day of release (blood values had risen) the infect. disease doc changed my antibiotics to Cipro orally and 10 freaking days of iv infusions before I went to work each a.m. of Cubicin (Daptomycin).  I had my last infusion this a.m.  and am clean of any bacteria (had gram negative rod, no MRSA thank God).  My onc wants to resume my AC next Thursday (that will be 4 wks. since my first one) and I am freaking out as I am petrified of what might happen again.  THey cannot guarantee me that I wont go neutropenic again.  (I also had the Neulasta shot day after chemo). Since my breast is clear of cellulitis but is still healing (could take 6 to 12 months to heal completely), they "hope" it doesn't happen again, but cannot guarantee me it won't.  Great, huh?  Onc said she will start me on a prophylactic antibiotic around day 3 after chemo to help in stopping any new infection.  I am frightened beyond belief at the prospect of next chemo.  I pray your sister does alright through all this.  I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy.  Please keep me posted on her progress and let her know I am sending her lots of cyber hugs.  Good luck. Linda

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 09:33PM - edited Jul 30, 2009 09:35PM by LRM216 Unless you are one of the unfortunate ladies that actually needs the epipen and are rushed to a hospital with anaphlactic shock from either Taxol of Taxotere, which indeed does happen, then the above-cited side effects usually occur only because the appropriate pre meds were not given and dripped for at least 1 hour before the chemo is given.  Then the Taxol and Taxotere MUST be dripped extremely slow.  Each of my treatments took over 4 1/2 hours to give, but they were given safely.  One time a first time taxotere user in the recliner next to be developed severe chest pains, horrific muscle spasms in her back, and was screaming out in pain.  I was afraid she was dying.  Thankfully, another chemo nurse took over, stopped the drip, flooded her with benedryl and she was back to normal within a minute.  They they continued the drip 1/2 hour later, extremely slowly, as it is supposed to be given and she was fine the rest of the way.  Turns out her first chemo nurse, didn't drip it slowly enough.  Linda

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 05:31PM LRM216 wrote: Hi KLee - I am about to have my last round of Taxotere (4 DD every three weeks) on the 9th.  I had 4 AC's DD every two weeks prior to the taxotere.  I asked the same questions you are asking prior to my beginning the taxotere and was told after the AC it was a walk in the park.  It may be that for you, and I am hoping it will be.  It has kicked my butt, but I am 62 and have been able to continue to raise my 14 yr. old grand-daughter and work full time every day but chemo day.  I have the treatments on a thursday, Neulasta shot (which is probably what has given me the most trouble) on Friday a.m and se's usually began on Saturday  and Sunday.  Two times they extended to Monday.  I have had bad bone and muscle aches which up until the third round I took nothing but Tylenol for - big mistake.  One I got the oxycodone and took it on schedule beginning late Friday night (before anything really started), and continued taking up until time I went back to work, I felt much, much better.  Make sure you get a strong enough pain med just in case you need it and don't be Joan of Arc as I tried to be the first two rounds.  I was supposed to take 2 pills every six hours.  I did not want to be in a coma like state, so I began Friday night taking 1/2 of one pill every 6 hours and by Saturday afternoon took 1 pill every six hours.  My aches and pains were minimal the third round and I plan on doing the same on the last one which I get on the 9th.  Biggest and worst - as it lasts much longer is the loss of tastebuds.  Anything I eat is disgusting, even water.  That is my biggest complaint at this point, which, since you are only 98 lbs, I hope doesn't effect you the same as it has me.  If it does, try to drink as many shakes as you can.  I did have a bit of neuropathy, but it is not bad at all.  Some of my toe nails have thickened and onc said I may lose them, but you must use bag balm or some sort of other cream on your feet constantly.  My fingernails are fine, and I know some gals have lost them, I don't think I will.  I do not want to scare you, as you may sail through it just fine, many do, but I do want you to make sure you have the proper pain meds on hand should you need them.  I went through way more than I had to only because I did not ask for stronger meds.  I had already lost my hair from the AC, but I do have peach fuzz (all white) growing as I take the treatments.  Good luck to you and keep us posted.  I wish you nothing but the best. Linda

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 10:17AM LRM216 wrote: Bio: Welcome to the boards, and I am so sorry you have to be here.  This will be the toughest part of your journey - until everything is known, and a treatment plan, whatever it may end up being, is chosen.  Then you dig in and fight this beast.  So much has to be determined, which will happen only after the lumpectomy and full pathology.  If you are deemed to be ER/PR +, you have many options, and the good probability of no chemo to begin with.  There would be hormonal drugs that you would be on, at least initially.  Now, they are not without their side effects, but each person reacts differently.  Some fly through with no problems, others have side effects.  If you should be triple negative, such as myself, then no hormonals will work on this cancer.  We have no targeted drugs, other than chemo, that can fight this very agressive cancer.  We are not without hope, and I stress that strongly should it be triple negative.  If you are ER/PR + (which is better) but HER positive, then you would be put on herceptin, which, again, does nothing for HER negative gals, whether hormone positive or negative.  Should your tumor be less than 5mm and your are triple neg, a lot of oncs forgo the chemo.  It will depend upon what your onc feels is the safest way to go.  Chemo was not pleasant and I was not one of the lucky ones that suffered minimal side effects.  There were times I just wanted to quit the whole thing and let nature take its course, but I was Stage 1, Grade 3 (triple neg is 98% of the time an agressive tumor no matter how small), and did not want to die.  I chose to use the biggest guns I could to fight this and am now glad that I did.  Remember - as this is very important- you only get one chance out of the gate to try to kill this crap FOREVER.  Don't be afraid of the chemo - it could be the deciding factor in whether you die of old age and not from cancer.  As bad a time as I had, not everyone does, and I am still here a year and a half after chemo - so it is doable.  Pleasant, not so much, but definitely doable.  I am a widow, had to keep working full time as a legal asst., raise my 15 year old grand-daughter (which oftentimes is more difficult than the chemo was!), and was 62, allbeit a young and healthy 62, upon diagnose.  If I can do it - anyone can do it! Keep the faith, put on your boxing gloves sister, and fight with all you have.  Keep us posted on your progress and final path report.  Should you be triple neg - most important that you choose an onc that is very familiar with treating triple neg, as it's a whole different ball game. Whatever path is chosen, know that I wish you nothing but complete success.  We are always here for you - 24/7.  God bless. Hugs, Linda

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 11:53AM LRM216 wrote: Marbletop: I have them yearly for my 20 year old symptomless fibroids.  Last one showed no change, but small amount of fluid in pelvis (which shouldn't be there at my age since I am post menopausal).  Had a pelvic MRI which showed nothing but the small amount of fluid.  Waited 3 months had another US and TV - same thing.  No cysts or masses found, but one radiologist read it seeing a possible left adnexal cystic mass - another read it as no adnexal mass - just small pocket of fluid (don't you just love it when you get differing opinions!).  So gyno sent me to onc-gyno for exam and to review all films.  He doesn't feel I have a problem and could not detect anything to worry about on all scans and MRIs, but has sent me for a CT of abdomen and pelvis to cover all the bases.  Had it yesterday.  Now I wait until next weds., as I climb the walls, to see him to find out the findings.  I am very nervous, even though I remain totally symptomless.  Just don't know what to think at this point, but am certainly nervous about what they may have found - maybe even if a different area, with the CT scan.  This disease (especially TN, as I am) is so damn sneaky, as we all are aware, so nervous I am, for sure.  At least you are on hormonals which are known to screw things in the pelvis up, and that it doesn't have to be cancer.  I don't even have that benefit. Wishing you the best, and I sure hoping mine will be ok as well.  Next month will be my third anniversary since diagnose with TN, I'm hoping it continues.  Ugh, I hate this disease and what it does to us. Linda

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2012 01:10PM LRM216 wrote: Just to let you know that while having an abd/pelvic CT for fibroid checkup reasons, they noticed a small "sclerotic" spot on the left side pedicle of my T12 vertebrae.  So the gyno wanted a full body bone scan due to my bc history.  Naturally, I had to be peeled off the wall over this.  Had the bone scan, and it showed absolutely nothing at all.  Both gyno and onc were not worried as they felt it was "wear and tear."  I am most grateful they were correct.  Also, none of my blood tests showed elevation in anything (not that that always matters).  So, I am wishing you the best, as well.  I too hope it is nothing.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 05:33PM LRM216 wrote: Never heard of it.  Are you sure you don't mean IDC (Invasive ductal carcinoma - the most common of all invasive cancers) - and consisting of "tubular" cell formation.  Tubular is a type of cancer cell and I think it's less agressive than most.  I know I had NO tubular formation and being triple negative, even though my Stage is 1, my cancer is a Grade three and agressive.  Hope someone else comes along to give more info than I could.  Best of luck to you on your journey, Robyn.
Posts.Title: Anyone have ITC? robynkk robynkk

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 12:37PM LRM216 wrote: Absolutely not.  I am stage 1, and finished my chemo in September, finished rads in early December - have my appt (3 month) with onc on Dec. 23.  She does not do any scans whatsover unless there are symptoms to indicate the need for same, and although she does not feel tumor markers are terribly accurate, she does them (had my first one shortly after first visit with her, which she uses as a baseline.  Fortunately my first and before chemo was normal and my second after chemo is even lower.  I will have my third one at my next visit.  She does complete blood work up on each 3 month visit and will continue to do so.  This will go on for the next 5 years at least.  I think after 2 or 3 years, I then go every 6 months, instead of the 3 months.  Good luck to you - you need to be watched with hormone responsive or triple negative. Linda
